title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: I named themone by one from east to west--Minchmoor, though it was hidden fromsight, where fled the great Montrose after the fatal rout ofPhiliphaugh; the broad foreheads of the Glenrath heights above my ownvale of Manor, Dollar Law, Scrape, the Drummelzier fells, the ruggedWormel, and, fronting me, the great Caerdon, with snow still lining itscrannies.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: I would soon be in Tweeddale again,and have Scrape and Dollar Law and Caerdon before my eyes, and hear thesing-song of Tweed running through the meadows.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: The haze was lifting off the great Manor Water hills; the Red Syke, thescene of the last night's escapade, looked very distant in the morninglight; and far beyond all Dollar Law and the high hills about Manorheadwere flushed with sunlight on their broad foreheads.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: Before usstretched the long upland moors, boggy, and cleft with deep ravines,with Scrape on the right, and straight in front, six miles beyond, thegreat broad crest of Dollar Law.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: Beyond that again came Dollar Law and the wild fellswhich give birth to the Tweed, the Yarrow, and the Annan.
